The jurors can accept that as the law, but do not have to accept Zimmerman's claim that he believed he was facing imminent severe harm.  And the fact that Zimmerman's injuries were minimal would justify such a conclusion.

Today, Zimmerman's defense lawyer explained, roughly, that if someone thinks he's facing severe harm in a confrontation, it's OK to go ahead and shoot the other person. It's not necessary to wait until substantial harm is being done.

If the jurors accept something like that as Florida law, I don't see how they can convict Zimmerman, and I don't see that there'll be any incentive in the state to keep brawls from escalating into shootings. Perhaps fights are already passé. Words escalate directly into shootings.

From another perspective, I hope the case makes it clear that community volunteers, whether watching for suspicious activity or merely weeding flower beds, should never confront anyone. That's for law enforcement officials.

The widespread US prosperity during the period from 1940 through 1945 was achieved at the cost of sacrifice of human life and health as well as environmental despoliation.

There was a rush to build poorly-engineered and misconceived machines that endangered their operators. The industrial processes used to produce them were just as poorly designed with water, air, and soil contamination that we are still working to alleviate.

An accelerated effort now to restore the environment damaged then could produce sustained economic activity.

Widespread, stable prosperity in the U S has occurred only once in the last hundred years. That was when we built huge quantities of economically useless things that were immediately destroyed.

Ships were built and sunk, tanks were built and blown up, airplanes were built and shot down, bombs were made and exploded. From an economic perspective WWII was a lot like digging ditches, filling them up, and then digging them again.

The U S remained prosperous through the fifties because the rest of the industrial world (German, Japan, etc.) had self destructed. America, with 5% of the world population, produced over 50% of the goods worldwide.

We need something with lots of jobs again. Whether it is a public works project like the Great Wall of China (yep, that's what it was) or colonizing Mars or researching medicine, anything that gives almost everyone a decent job is going to help. We could start by rebuilding our infrastructure (roads, bridges, sewers, etc.) and doubling the number of teachers.

The old standby of starting a war probably will not work again, because it will be fought by a few technicians and robots. Large scale combat would probably lead to the end of humanity.

Dude, you never lived on a farm -- did you?

Farming is an excellent way to starve to death -- bad crops, insects, bad weather, failure to rotate crops, bad choices about the economy -- and you go from having a farm to starving on your farm in a nanosecond.

People -- humanity in general -- are far wealthier, happier and better fed TODAY with 1% of the population doing farming than we were in the 19th century with 90% having to do farming. Today 1% of those who farm can easy feed not just all of America, but a good chunk of the rest of the world.

Even the worst employer is probably "kinder" than Mother Nature, who doesn't care if she turns your fields into the Dust Bowl, or sends a scourge of locusts to eat all your grain.

There is nothing wrong with separating the farm bill from the Food Stamp program and lefties here have their panties in a twist over nothing. No conservative wants to end the Food stamp program -- at most, they want to return it to pre-Obama levels (7.5% of the population -- not 15%!!!).

When America was mainly a farming society, it was possible to support oneself with work and not be denied the opportunity to do that work if one had access even to a small portion of land. This was the reason that ex-slaves were promised land ("40 acres and a mule") and part of the reason that homesteading was encouraged in the American west, even if it meant taking more and more land from American Indians. The money economy now means in order to work you must be accepted by an employer and, if you can't get employment commensurate with the costs of providing food, shelter, clothing and other basic necessities, too bad. That's the brutal truth imposed by the "wonderful" marketplace (which has become a new religion on some circles).

The point is this: we don't live in an agricultural society any more. The poor can't support themselves if there are no jobs or jobs, like working at Walmart, that don't pay enough to get by. So, we have created imperfect and sometimes flawed ways of trying to help people cope with what we have, the money is everything economy.

The Republicans in the House have really shot themselves in the foot this time by separating the Farm Bill and food assistance (SNAP). They have invited making the farm subsidy programs part of the future partisan agenda. Why should the populous states vote to support programs that go to the rural states when those states vote, again and again, against everything the populated states need?
